|region5 = |ref5 = |rels= |langs= Albanian, Italian |rels = Christian: Italo-
Albanian Catholic Church  |related = Albanians, Italians Albanian
diaspora Arvanites}} The 'ArbÃ«reshÃ«' are a linguistic and ethnic Albanian
minority community living in southern Italy, especially the regions of
Basilicata, Molise, Apulia, Calabria and Sicily. Today ArbÃ«reshe are largely assimilated into
the Italian society [http://books.google.bg/books?id=pJu5veUAo7kC&pg=PA60&d-
q=Arberesh+people&hl=bg&sa=X&ei=K630Ud2sG8LItQb0poGgCQ&ved=0CFQQ6AEwBQ#v=onepag-
e&q=Arberesh%20people&f=false The Language and Politics, Edinburgh Textbooks in
Applied Linguistics, John Earl Joseph, Edinburgh University Press, 2006, ISBN
0748624538, p. 60.] and they count in Italy between 80,000 [http://bo-
oks.google.bg/books?id=hyR_dqdZ5SQC&pg=PA110&dq=Arb%C3%ABresh%C3%AB+people&hl=b-
g&sa=X&ei=4aj0UaOSBozDtAaXhoCwCQ&ved=0CDUQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=Arb%C3%ABresh%C3-
%AB%20people&f=false Handbook of ethnotherapies, Christine E. Gottschalk-
Batschkus, Joy C. Green, BoD â Books on Demand, 2002, ISBN 3831141843, p.
110.] and 100,000 people. [http://books.google.bg/books?id=31RhzMMTTd-
IC&pg=PA18&dq=Arb%C3%ABresh%C3%AB+people&hl=bg&sa=X&ei=eKb0UbSZO4bXtAap4YGQDw&v-
ed=0CC4Q6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=Arb%C3%ABresh%C3%AB%20people&f=false Ethnobotany in
the New Europe: People, Health and Wild Plant Resources, vol. 14, Manuel Pardo
de Santayana, Andrea Pieroni, Rajindra K. Puri, Berghahn Books, 2010, ISBN
1845458141, p. 18.]

They settled in Southern Italy in the 15th to 18th centuries AD in several waves
of migrations, following the death of the Albanian national hero George
Kastrioti Skanderbeg and the gradual conquest of Albania and throughout the
Byzantine Empire by the Ottoman Turks. The ArbÃ«reshÃ« have their own distinct
culture and have been able to preserve the original Albanian
identity. [http://www.comunediacquaformosa.it/storia/STORIA1.HTML Gli
albanesi d'Italia] Their culture is determined by the main features that
are found in language, religion, traditions, customs, art and gastronomy, still
jealously preserved, with the awareness of belonging to a specific ethnic group.
Over the centuries, the ArbÃ«reshÃ« have managed to maintain and develop their
identities, thanks to their stubbornness and cultural value exercised mainly by
the two religious communities of the Eastern Rite Greek-Byzantine, based in
Calabria, the "Collegio Corsini" (1732) and then "Corsini-Sant'Adriano" in 1794
and Sicily in the "Seminario Greco-Albanese of Palermo" (1735) then transferred
to Piana degli Albanesi in 1945. Today, most of the fifty ArbÃ«reshÃ« communities
still preserve the Byzantines belonging to the Italo-Albanian Church of Eastern
Rite. They belong to two Eparchies: to Lungro for Albanians in southern Italy,
and that of Piana degli Albanesi for the Albanians of Sicily. The Byzantine
Eparchy is the most important for the maintenance of the characteristics
religious, ethnic, linguistic, and traditional identity of the ArbÃ«reshÃ«
community.

]] The ArbÃ«reshÃ« speak ArbÃ«risht, an old variant of Albanian spoken in southern
Albania. The ArbÃ«resh language is of particular interest to students of the
modern Albanian language as it represents the sounds, grammar, and vocabulary of
pre-Ottoman Albania. In Italy the ArbÃ«reshÃ« language is protected by the law n.
482 concerning the protection of ethnic minorities and linguistic
history. [http://www.camera.it/parlam/leggi/99482l.htm]

They are scattered throughout southern Italy and Sicily, and constitute one of
the largest ethno-linguistic minorities in Italy. To define their "nation",
ArbÃ«resh speakers use the term ArbÃ«ria. Even if the reference is always
Albania.
